data.text: Bad Knee Pain when Cycle Touring

Anyone experience knee pain while riding? I had bad knee pain so rested for nearly 2 weeks my knee felt better, today is my first day back on the bike and its already hurting again. I've done over 2000 miles on my bike prior to starting my tour so I know its not my bike or the way I ride it. Not sure what to do now, wether to continue or not.
Which bit of the knee? I get ITB syndrome- it's the outside of the knee. Really you're going to need to get someone medical to have a look at it.
data.author: Matt Mis

data.text: Maybe go to the doctor and have that checked? A good ortho specialist should be able to tell you what’s happening. That way, you can make whatever adjustments you need to make from an informed standpoint instead of guessing at variables and possibly making the problem worse. Good luck! I feel for you. I have pretty aggressive osteoarthritis in my right knee and have had to lay off prolonged climbs, make peace with slower average mph, and not being able to ride daily.
data.author: Alejandro Lizardi

data.text: i fully agree. i just yesterday (!) had a massage therapist re-work my quads, glutes and calves in order to re-align the entire leg of the knee which had been bothering me badly for weeks... it feels MUCH better today... i will return to be sure that the old mis-alignment doesn't re-assert itself...
data.author: Miko Sloper

data.text: Yes I get knee pain and some days they ache I try and manage by not running too bigger gear with the load. Without getting the knees checked it would be hard to say if it’s just pain and tiredness from the k’s and weight (which is what I have I think) and not injury. If it’s hard to tolerate you should get it checked.
data.author: Kim Mcfadden

data.text: The same thing happened to me on my last trip, I suffered in the first week, I was in pain when I put my foot on the pedal, The pain began to lessen with time and the days passed, it disappeared completely, time was the medicine.
data.author: غويلب محمد رضا

data.text: If you're clipped into the pedals, the position and angle of the clips - and hence your feet/knees- can make a big difference.
data.author: Richard Frankel

data.text: I abandoned clips and went to flats and my knee pain has disappeared.
data.author: Phil Metcalfe

data.text: bad bike fit will stress knees, back and hands
data.author: Clyde Slade

data.text: I'm not sure it could be that really as I've done over 2000 miles clipped on my bike before I started touring and never had so much as an ache.
data.author: Nathan Rice-Smith

data.text: It just so happens that I started my tour 2 weeks ago and suddenly got unbearable inner knee pain on 1 leg which I have never had before. I had to abandon it and get train home after 400 miles which is so frustrating. It has not eased up after almost 10 days - will be seeing a physio tomorrow - it’s not related to my cleat position or seat height before anyone suggests this and It is certainly not due to the sudden increase in mileage.
data.author: Neil Smith

data.text: saddle set back. Crank arm length. Things can change even by free mm over a CV prof of time, like seat post sagging / going down. So, it won't hurt to check. Sometimes, it may be that you need to use higher tyre pressure diye to the luggage. But if the cycle or saddle height has not changed for a long time, do meet a doctor.
data.author: Mahesh T Pai

data.text: exactly the same as me, even the train home, apart from I have no home so it was my mums!! Let me know what the outcome is from your physio as I would be very interested. Wish you speedy recovery.
data.author: Nathan Rice-Smith

data.text:
https://road.cc/content/feature/how-set-your-saddle-height-166709
How to set your saddle height - get it right for improved comfort and power
road.cc
data.author: Mahesh T Pai

data.text: Change the saddle position
data.author: Javier Colón

data.text: Your knee has muscles, ligaments, tendons, bursae, capsule, and dozens of other stuff that can be the cause. Check in with a good Ortho and possibly physio/osteo.
data.author: Matthias Tango

data.text: It happens to more people than you would have thought. I think (and I'm no doctor) that it's to do with you cycling with out panniers and its all ok then you put 30kgs on a bike, cycle the same way/speed and your knees go WOOOO BUDDY, that ain't cool, ease off a bit till I'm used to all this weight. So many people start a tour then 10 days later have to rest up a bit while their knees get some tlt....Time and rest I've found.
data.author: Barry Warner

data.text:
Don't stop the tour. Take a day off and go see a good massage therapist. Also check your bikefit if you can. If you can see a massage therapist make sure they work the TFL, Glut Medius, IT band, and the tendons around the knee. I would do a full hour of just the lower body. This will help but you should see someone regularly. I also battle with knee pain and have started stretching regularly and massaging myself more often and it help a lot. https://youtu.be/hh1gpeVtt2k
IT Band Release Self Massage (Leg/Knee Pain Relief)
youtube.com
data.author: Gerald Raton

data.text: I know that my cadence drops significantly when not touring and so does my riding position. When touring, I am spinning along and sitting a little more upright. I only push hard on the hills. I get some pain on the outside of my right knee from time to time but it's not significant and it usually goes away. Self massage wouldn't hurt. Ice? Rest? Best of luck.
data.author: Marshall Bradbury

data.text: Thank you all for your comments and suggestions, I'm in a bit of a funk with it all at the moment. I will certainly try all that I can before giving up. Worrying about it and dealing with the pain just takes all the fun out of for me. I hope I can find a solution.
data.author: Nathan Rice-Smith

data.text: Tie the leg with bandage..
data.author: Азамат Марападдинов

data.text: I had the same problem and adjusted my seat. They made it 7 cm higher
data.author: Eveline Van Hooren

data.text: It's probably because you are riding in to low a gear. You will have to rest till you heal, and then use higher gear and build up the muscles around your knee.
data.author: Pdl Breaking

data.text: Low cadence might cause knee pain. Try to keep cadenca at around 80-85.
data.author: Juha Koivisto

data.text: Even 90 is fine
data.author: Supp Suppinger

data.text: For cyclists with knee pain stretching the hip flexors helps. Especially if you are using clipless pedals. A word from a physiotherapist.
data.author: Agris Piebalgs

data.text: lots of good stretches on YouTube.
data.author: Bettegail Shively

data.text: Are you stretching?
data.author: Lev Neyman

data.text: Knee problems are rarely a result of damage in the knee, but often a result of a body imbalance , perhaps the IT band, Hip flexors etc. A good physio recently published a report where they had cured a bike riders knee issues - the rider was about to have surgery. The treatment too technical for me to recall, but was a holistic strength training, massage of fascia etc
data.author: Mark Sippings

data.text:
https://www.cvs.com/shop/home-health-care/braces-supports/thigh-knee-braces
Thigh & Knee Braces | Knee Support - CVS Pharmacy
cvs.com
data.author: Gary WiseOwl

data.text:
this video helped me to set up my bike better and also make my knee pain getting better https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lg9lqqaDLTI
How to FIX Knee Pain on the Bike - BikeFitTuesdays
youtube.com
data.author: Sandra Peters

data.text: Looking back at the saddle is too much. small or too advanced saddle
data.author: Barthelemy Herve

data.text: I use fasting for one week when knees problèm . It works Great . One week without eating. Just you drink . For me its acidosis. You have to much acid inside so you have pain . Need detox protocol then all things will be fixed ....or not . It dépends of your ability to let body repair himself . When no digestion body repair itself . This is my own technique . If pain no eat till pain dissapear
data.author: Stéphane Sintès

data.text: I had experienced some left knee pain by trying to really ride faster then I wanted to by trying to keep up with others. I have found out by keeping your cadence higher by downshifting in an easier gear that this helped my knee pain to go away. You might want to try this to see if it helps on your tour.
data.author: Robert Zehr

data.text: 1000 suggestions for Knee pain. Maybe a rest of 14day was to short.
data.author: Jackb Hubendubel

data.text: but there is a basic rule of medicine that you should first heed before trying out all possible tips (and later maybe nothing helps) Diagnostic before therapy
data.author: Jackb Hubendubel

data.text: Before you go to a doc check your seat placement. Too far forward or too high = knee pain, similar too far back/ low. Google it and adjust your seat. I had the same issue, went to,ortho but resolved the issue by adjusting my seat. Good luck and safe travels.
data.author: Brian Smith

data.text:
Have you checked out something like this: https://www.betterpt.com/post/cycling-to-get-healthy-tips-for-avoiding-neck-and-knee-pain
Tips for Avoiding Neck and Knee Pain from Cycling - BetterPT Blog
betterpt.com
data.author: Geof Tillotson

data.text: Depends on where the knee pain is. On top the top of the knee can indicate your saddle-height is too low.
data.author: Jason Underwood

data.text: It's not here that you have to ask but to an orthopedic surgeon...🤣😂🤣
data.author: Michel de Marais

data.text: I don't feel much pain at all while I'm riding but I look as not going to be able to get off the bike when I stop and as for getting back on the bike and crawling around like a cripple while of the bike is all forgotten as soon as I start peddling
data.author: Glen Mcneil

data.text: Two things spring to my mind. Was your 2000 miles prior to the tours loaded with gear? If it wasn't you could be trying to use too high a gear. Spinning the pedals faster is much easier on the knees. Are you using clipless pedals? If you are try switching to flats. Your feet can move around more and the load can be shared by a wider range of movement and surfaces in your knee joint.
data.author: Mark Perry

data.text: I'm a therapist with many bike tours under my belt, along with bilateral ACL reconstruction secondary to injuries from dance and martial arts... what you are experiencing may be related to a structural abnormality or more likely, repetitive stress; I try and vary my overall biomechanic positions CONTINUOUSLY while I ride, and it is the reason why I don't like "lock in" pedal systems. The key is to not stay in one position too long: flat pedals with adjustable plastic toe clips allow me diverse foot positions, sometimes using my other leg to pull up on the pedal more, allowing the sore knee to rest more, but still be involved, sometimes flipping the pedal upside down and pedaling more with my heel; sometimes pedaling with my toes pointing in or toes pointing out, vary seat height or handlebar position, which allows me to lean forward or lean back,, etc. The key is too not stay in one position too long...slowing down,, Ibuprofen ( with food in my stomach) and rest helps; massaging the knee area with Tiger balm at night also feels good....
data.author: Louis Matti Tornyai

data.text: You did the right thing to refuse to ride through pain. As you can see there are various and even conflicting ideas about how to avoid it. I encourage you to continue refusing to ride in pain.
data.author: David Markun

data.text: Before you go on a long trip on your bike, it's compulsory to do quite a lot of training. We talk about months. With, and without luggage. If not your body will not be prepared for the hard work it is cycling for hours, day after day, week after week. Simple as that.
data.author: Trygve Rolfsnes

data.text: It can be for many reasons: A wrong fit of your Body-Bicycle can give you knee pain. (front knee pain or back knee pain depending of whats wrong with that fit) and you can fix it with proper fit. // A heavy bike with fast drive train will make you press too much on your knees, you can fix it with a drive train with very slow gear if is not too late. // For anything else visit your doctor.
data.author: Jo En Pausa

data.text: Yeah I have this on and off on all my tours. I'm several weeks into this year's tour and it has only just shown up in the last few days. If it gets really bad I wear a knee brace and that helps, though it's not terribly comfortable to wear.
data.author: Cath Wood

data.text: I concur with what Lev said... stretching! Stretch your whole body, especially your legs two or three times a day. A ton of knee pain is actually muscle and tendon related.
data.author: Ryan Tew

data.text: I suggest getting an MRI. Find out what's going on with your knee. Then consult with a Physical Therapist to learn what you can do to improve your situation.
data.author: Byron Kuster
